lg.l: Written above a Thousand Years ago, and relating to the YEAR 1709.
With Explanatory NOTES.
By T. N. Philomath.
Written in the Year 1709.
LAST Year was published a Paper of Predictions, pretended to be written by one Isaac Bickerstaff, Esq;
but the true Design of it was to ridicule the Art of Astrology, and expose its Professors as ignorant, or Impostors.
Against this Imputation, Dr. Partrige hath learnedly vindicated himself in his Almanack for that Year.
FOR a farther Defence of this famous Art, I have thought fit to present the World with the following Prophecy.
The Original is said to be of the famous Merlin, who lived about a Thousand Years ago:
And the following Translation is two Hundred Years old;
for it seemeth to be written near the End of Henry the Seventh's Reign.
I found it in an old Edition of Merlin's Prophecies;
imprinted at London by Johan Haukyns, in the Year 1530, Page 39.
I set it down Word for Word, in the old Orthography, and shall take Leave to subjoin a few explanatory Notes.

SEVEN and TEN addyd to NINE,Fraunce hir Woe thys is the Sygne,Tamys Ryvere twys y-frozen,Stoffe to fattyn Londe,Fraunce that evere he was borne.Symnele shall again miscarrye:Norways Pryd again shall marrey.Englonde:Englonde shall be no more,Geryon shall have three Hades agayne,Hapsburge makyth them but twayne.
Of
Walke sans wetyng Shoes ne Hosen.
Then cometh foorth, Ich understonde
From Towne of
An herdie Chiftan, woe the Morne
To
Then shall the Fyshe beweyle his Bosse;
Nor shall grin Berrys make up the Losse,
Yonge
And
And from the Tree where Blosums fele,
Rife Fruit shall come, and all is wele.
Reaums shall daunce Honde in Honde
And it shall be merye in old
Then old
And no Man shall be sorie therefore.
Till

NOTESSeven and Ten, &c.] This Line describes the Year when these Events shall happen._January.Tamys Ryvere twys, &c.] The River Thames frozen twice in one Year, so as Men do walk on it, is a very signal Accident;_.From Towne of Stoffe, &c.] This is a plain Designation of the Duke of Marlborough._Marle, and every Body knows, that Borough is a Name for a Town;_.Then shall the Fyshe, &c.] By the Fish is understood the Dauphin of France, as the King's eldest Sons are called:_Burgundy, called the Bosse, which is an old English word for Hump-shoulder, or Crook-back, as that Duke is known to be:_Grin Berrys, in the next Line, is meant the young Duke of Berry, the Dauphin's third Son, who shall not have Valour or Fortune enough to supply the Loss of his Eldest Brother.Yonge Symnele, &c.] By Symnele is meant the pretended Prince of Wales; who, if he offereth to attempt any Thing against England, shall miscarry as he did before._Lambert Symnel is the Name of a young Man noted in our Histories for personating the Son (as I remember) of Edward the Fourth.And Norways Pryd, &c.] I cannot guess who is meant by Norways Pride1Queen ANNE. The Prophecy means, that she should marry a second Time, and have Children that would live., perhaps the Reader may, as well as the Sense of the two following Lines.Reaums, &c.] Reaums, or as the Word is now, Realms, is the old Name of Kingdoms:_Union, with the Felicities that shall attend it._Old England shall be no more, and yet no Man shall be sorry for it._England is no more;_Britain.Geryon shall &c.] This Prediction, although somewhat obscure, is wonderfully adapt._Geryon is said to have been a King of Spain, whom Hercules slew._Spain shall have three Kings;_Portugal, which properly is part of Spain, there are now two Rivals for Spain;
Seven and Ten make Seventeen, which I explain seventeen Hundred, and this Number added to Nine makes the Year we are now in;_
for it must be understood of the Natural Year, which begins the First of

which perhaps hath not fallen out for several Hundred Years before; and is the Reason why some Astrologers have thought that this Prophecy could never be fulfilled, because they imagined such a Thing could never happen in our Climate
One Kind of Stuff used to fatten Land is called
and this Way of Expression is after the usual dark Manner of old Astrological Predictions
It is here said, he shall lament the Loss of the Duke of
And the Prophecy seemeth to mean, that he should be overcome, or slain._
By the
And this is a very plain Prediction of our happy
It is added, that
And, indeed, properly speaking,
for the whole Island is one Kingdom, under the Name of
It was a Fiction of the Poets, that he had three Heads, which the Author sayeth he shall have again._
That is,
which is now wonderfully verified:_
For, besides the King of
Charles and Philip._Charles being descended from the Count of Hapsburgh, Founder of the Austrian Family, shall soon make those Heads but two;_Philip, and driving him out of Spain.
But
by overturning
SOME of these Predictions are already fulfilled;
and it is highly probable the rest may be in due Time:
And, I think, I have not forced the Words, by my Explanation, into any other Sense than what they will naturally bear.
If this be granted, I am sure it must be also allowed, that the Author (whoever he was) was a Person of extraordinary Sagacity;
and that Astrology, brought to such Perfection as this, is, by no Means, an Art to be despised;
whatever Mr. Bickerstaff, or other merry Gentlemen, are pleased to think.
As to the Tradition of these Lines, having been writ in the Original by Merlin;
I confess, I lay not much Weight upon it:
But it is enough to justify their Authority, that the Book from whence I have transcribed them, was printed 170 Years ago, as appeareth by the Title Page.
For the Satisfaction of any Gentleman, who may be either doubtful of the Truth, or curious to be informed;
I shall give Order to have the very Book sent to the Printer of this Paper, with Directions to let any Body see it that pleaseth;
because I believe it is pretty scarce. 102-0171
